abstract.p: Two important issues in the analysis of association among financial markets are the degree of dependence and the underlying shape commanding the cross-market dependencies, so that any model used to describe this association must cope with both the issues. In the study presented in this article, we approach the modelling of dependence in two stages. The first stage is based on modelling the dependence between the returns of two assets by means of a single Archimedean copula, whereas the second one takes advantage of the mixture between copulas to gain the necessary flexibility to capture different tail dependence patterns. Both stages have been followed in modelling the dependence among the daily returns of seven Latin American country indices, a regional index and a worldwide index. Our findings have important implications for portfolio risk management.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Knowledge, specification and estimation of dependence structures among financial asset returns is nowadays crucial in most financial applications like portfolio management, control of risk clustering, or pricing and hedging, to mention a few. In spite of the countless studies of dependence in financial markets, the unveiling of the dependence structure is still one of the main challenges that researchers are faced with.

The classical approach to dependence is based on the multivariate normal distribution. When assuming multivariate normality, the inference is based on mean-variance analysis. Nevertheless, the evidence against the univariate normal distribution as an adequate model for real assets is actually incontestable. Regarding emerging markets, the departure from univariate normality in financial returns has been extensively documented by many authors,1 even at the univariate level, meaning that inference based on such assumption is questionable.

This empirical evidence shows that investment decisions based on linear correlation could be dangerous. Portfolio optimisation theory based on the multivariate normal distribution favours the investment in assets with low correlation, in order to hedge the portfolio or, in other words, to benefit from diversification. However, without multivariate normality, two pairs of markets can have equal linear correlation but very different dependence structures. For instance, it is quite easy to find pairs of countries with similar correlation but very different number of market crashes.2 This different dependence structure can result in diversification benefits greater or lower than those indicated by classical correlation analysis.

A different approach to the multivariate analysis of financial returns is based on separating the study of the univariate distributions from that of the dependence relationships, using copula models for the dependence structure. A copula is a function connecting the univariate marginal distributions and the multivariate distribution. The variety of copula functions already described in the literature (Nelsen 1998) provides us with a wide range of models of dependence structure, although some of them are inadequate to financial markets, as discussed in this article. Recently, many authors have relied on copula functions for modelling the dependence structure among financial markets (or variables).3

This article presents the results of a study of the dependence structure among seven Latin American markets.4The performance of a range of models, based on different copula functions, on a data set of daily returns, is assessed and compared. Our study is limited to pair-wise dependence. More specifically, we have used only continuous two-dimensional copulas, either single Archimedean copulas or mixtures of two Archimedean copulas. The models used here are relatively simple, when compared to others used in the literature. The approach of this study is based on an exploratory examination of the dependence structure, in special the tail dependence, trying subsequently a range of simple models and using fitting measures to select the best performer.

In financial studies, an important aspect of dependence is tail dependence. Roughly speaking, lower (upper) tail dependence between two financial markets exists when the probability of joint negative (positive) extreme events is higher than what could be predicted from the marginal distributions. Recent empirical studies show that turbulent, quiet and expansive periods are characterised by different levels of dependence, leading to tail dependence being stronger on the lower than on the upper tail. We show here that this is the case for the markets analysed in this article. Therefore, models of dependence that allow for asymmetric patterns of tail dependence are needed in this context.

Bivariate normality can be separated in two components: (a) the univariate normal marginals, specified through mean and standard deviation parameters (μ, σ), and (b) the Gaussian copula, specified through a correlation coefficient (ρ). In financial returns data, the hypothesis of univariate normal marginals is usually rejected, due to the presence of skewness and (positive) kurtosis, the latter being an almost universal trait of financial returns. If the skewness of the marginals is low, we can use marginal t distributions to capture the fat tails which are typical of financial returns. On the other hand, when there is tail dependence, as in the data used in this study, the Gaussian dependence must be rejected. An alternative model for dependence would be the t copula, but the degree of tail dependence must be the same on both sides, which is not the case in our sample. We have to deal, not only with tail dependence but also with asymmetric tail dependence.

Once the Gaussian and t copulas and, more generally, elliptical copulas have been discarded, we have assessed the performance of a set of single Archimedean copulas. The association parameters of these copulas are estimated through [semi] parametric methods. Next, we move one step further, fitting mixture copula models to our data set. The performance of the different single copulas is taken into account when choosing the components or the mixtures. Specifically, our model mixes Archimedean copulas that capture different tail dependence patterns. As Rodriguez (2007) we let the data ascribe the degree of asymmetry through the weight assigned to each distribution. Mixture copula models are estimated using the EM-algorithm (Dempster et al. 1977). The goodness of fit for the different models is assessed in various ways.

Besides these methodological aspects, and regarding the emerging markets data analysed in this article, this study presents
Evidence of asymmetric tail dependence, allowing the rejection of elliptical copulas as dependence models for emerging market returns.
A comparison of different single Archimedean copulas, showing the inferiority of the Joe copula and similar performance for the Clayton, Frank and Gumbel copulas.
Evidence that some of the 2-copula mixtures provide models which are not only superior to those based on single Archimedean copulas but also flexible enough to satisfactorily deal with the complexity of the dependence structure, in particular with asymmetric tail dependence.
Evidence that after controlling for conditional volatility both the cross-country and country–world dependence structure do not change significantly. The goodness of fit assessed through the hit test improves substantially.

The layout of the article is as follows. The second section provides the basic copula theory, including Archimedean and mixture copulas. In the third section, we provide the details of the estimation of Archimedean models and the different methods to assess the goodness of fit. The fourth section presents the basic statistics of our data set. In the fifth section, we present and discuss the empirical results of our study. Finally, the last section is devoted to the conclusions.

sec.title: Basic Definitions
sec.p: In the statistical literature, Sklar (1959) was the first to coin the term copula, to describe the function that ‘joins’ univariate distribution functions to form multivariate ones. We restrict ourselves here to continuous 2-dimensional copulas.5 A 2-dimensional copula is basically a bivariate cumulative distribution function (cdf) with uniformly distributed margins in [0,1]. The most important result of copula theory is the Sklar’s theorem.

p.italic: Sklar’s Theorem: Let H be the joint cdf of a pair of continuous variables X and Y. Then there exists a unique continuous 2-copula C such that
p.disp-formula: (1) H (x, y) = p [X < x, Y < y] = C (FX (x), FY (y)), (x, y) ∈ R2.

sec.p: Conversely, if C is a continuous 2-copula and both F1 and F2 are continuous cdf’s, the function H = C (F1, F2) is a bivariate cdf with marginals F1 and F2.

In general, copula models contain one or more parameters called association parameters. When there is only one parameter, it can be seen as a measure of dependence. Given a copula C, the survival copula associated to C is defined as6
(2) C* (u, v) = u + v – 1 + C (1 – u, 1 – v).
If c (u, v) is the density of distribution defined by C (u, v), the density corresponding to C* (u, v) is given by c* (u, v) = c (l – u, 1 – v).

A pair (X, Y ) with joint probability density function f (x, y) is said to have an elliptical distribution when the contours of constant density (i.e., the curves f (x, y) = const) are concentrical ellipses. The bivariate normal and t distributions are the classical examples. The elliptical copulas are the copulas of elliptical distributions. Of course, the ellipses are distorted when transforming (X, Y) into (U, V), but the symmetry is preserved, so that the dependence patterns are the same in the two tails and in particular, C (u, v) = C* (u, v).

Ellipticity is a very strong assumption for models that are to be applied to financial data. In particular, for the data discussed in this study, it must be discarded, due to the asymmetry in the tail dependence. It is worth mentioning that the asymmetry of the copula has been related to portfolio skewness. Patton (2002) has shown that the asymmetry of the copula leads to portfolio skewness, even when the distribution of the individual assets involved in the portfolio is symmetric.

sec.title: Tail Dependence
sec.p:
In many finance or insurance applications, we need models that allow for a stronger dependence between extreme losses (e.g., when stock markets collapse) than between extreme gains. Thus, tail dependence becomes a key issue when choosing a copula for modelling the dependence between the returns of two assets. In the bivariate case, tail dependence measures can be related to the lower (λL) or the upper tail (λU). Formally, for a probability α, we define lower and upper tail dependence at level α as the conditional probabilities:
(3) λL(α)=C(α,α)α, λU(α)=C*(α,α)α .

The asymptotic tail dependence parameters, that is, the limits of these expressions as α → 0, exist for the main copulas found in the literature. Due to their symmetry, elliptical copulas have λL = λU, this unique parameter being zero for the Gaussian copula and positive for the t copula. Finding evidence of tail dependence in the data suggests immediately discarding the Gaussian copula as a model for the dependence of asset returns.7 Also, finding asymmetry in tail dependence is an argument against the t copula. Estimates of the asymptotic dependence parameters help to detect the asymmetry. To get such estimates, we choose α small enough (we use α = 0.01 in the subsection ‘Tail Dependence’ under the fourth section ‘Description of the Data’) and approximate λU (α) and λL (α) by the corresponding sample proportions.
Asymmetry in tail dependence cannot be modelled through elliptical copulas. We see next how to deal with asymmetry in the Archimedean class of copulas.

sec.title: Archimedean Copulas
sec.p:
A (bivariate) Archimedean copula is defined by the formula
(4) C (u, v) = φ–1 (φ(u) + φ(v)),
where φ: [0, 1] → [0, +∞] is a continuous decreasing convex function, with φ (1) = 0 and φ (0) = +∞, and φ–1 is the inverse of φ.8We call φ the generator of the copula C.

Two well-known scale-invariant measures of association are the Spearman (ρ) and Kendall (τ) rank correlations, the so-called non-parametric correlation coefficients. Both can be derived from the copula function. In particular, for the Kendall τ,
(5) τ =4 ∫01 ∫01 C (u,v) dC (u,v) −1.

It is interesting to note that, since the survival copula is the copula of the transformed variables U* = 1 – U and V* = 1 – V, both C and C* have the same Kendall correlation. For Archimedean copulas, the Kendall τ can be also expressed in terms of the generator of the copula.9
Table 1 presents the four Archimedean copulas used in this study.10

sec.title: Mixture Copulas
sec.p:
Our mixture copulas are formed by two copulas, called here the components of the mixture. If C1 and C2 are copulas and w1, w2  0 are weights (w1 + w2 = 1), the formula
(6) C (u, v) = w1 C1 (u, v) + w2 C2 (u, v)
defines a mixture copula. Mixture copulas can be used to combine the tail dependence properties of the component copulas, for instance, when C1 has lower tail dependence but not upper tail dependence, and C2 the opposite way. Extension to more than two components is straightforward, but less useful, at least for bivariate copula.11

Mixture copulas have already been used in financial research. Fortin and Kuzmics (2002) suggest replacing by mixtures the common one-parameter copula models used as models of dependence in many applications. They fitted mixtures of an elliptical model and a non-elliptical model to a set of European stocks, testing the weight of the non-elliptical component by means of a likelihood ratio test. Chollete et al. (2005) have also argued in favour of mixture copulas. The idea of using a mixture copula model to allow for possible asymmetries in the dependence is not entirely new. Patton (2003) has proposed an interesting mixture copula, based on a modification of the BB7 copula of Joe (1997),12 in order to correct for the fact that even when the two tail dependence measures are equal there is still some (slight) asymmetry in the Joe–Clayton copula, due simply to the functional form of this copula. He calls this model the ‘symmetrized Joe–Clayton’ copula. With the aim of gaining flexibility when modelling the dependence structure, Hu (2003) proposes a mixture copula approach to measure cross-market dependence. She models across-market dependence among four developed stock market indices,13 using a mixture of a Gaussian copula, a Gumbel copula and a Gumbel survival copula. Rodriguez (2007) and Chollete et al. (2009) make use of regime-switching copula models to estimate the dependence countries. The underlying idea is that, instead of using weights for mixing copulas, they allow for two different regimes or shapes of dependence. Rodriguez (2007) works with Latin American and Asian countries in a bivariate framework, while Chollete et al. (2009) work with Latin American and G5 countries in a multivariate framework.

We have explored in this study a variety of Archimedean copula mixture models. First, the Clayton–Survival Clayton mixture (with w1 = w2 = 0.5) has been used, contrasting it with the four single Archimedean copulas already mentioned, the Clayton, Frank, Gumbel and Joe copulas. Then, other mixtures have been tried, relaxing also the constraint w1 = w2 = 0.5. The mixture then becomes a model with three parameters, the weight of the first component (the other weight is 1 w) and the parameters θ1 and θ2 of the two components. We have used in this analysis the following mixture models: Clayton/Gumbel (CG), Clayton/ Frank (CF), Clayton/Survival Clayton (CSC) and Gumbel/Survival Gumbel (GSG).

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: There are two main approaches for fitting copula models to bivariate data. The first one, appropriate for single one-parameter copulas, but not for copulas with more than one parameter, uses the relationship between a correlation measure and the parameter of the copula. For the most popular Archimedean copulas, there are simple formulas relating the Kendall τ to the parameter θ.

The second approach searches parameter estimates through the optimisation of a measure of the goodness of fit. One such measure is the likelihood function. The maximum likelihood (ML) estimation approach is widely known and much favoured in academic research. Other measures derived from the likelihood, like the Akaike information criterion (AIC), are currently used in model selection. The extension of the ML approach to mixture copulas is usually done by means of the so-called EM (expectation-maximisation) algorithm. Other measures of goodness of fit are distance measures, of L2 or L∞ type, between the empirical (data based) copula and the theoretical copula. These measures are much simpler to grasp than likelihood-based measures.

Graphical methods for identifying the copula model, like the Genest and Rivest method (Genest and Rivest 1993), chi-plots (Abberger 2003; Fisher and Switzer 2001) or Kendall plots (Genest and Boies 2003), have not been used here, since we have favoured an approach based on the examination of the tail dependence, followed by a comparison among plausible models based on numerical measures.

sec.title: Estimation from the Kendall τ
sec.p: As we have mentioned in the subsection ‘Archimedean Copulas’, there are simple formulas relating the Kendall τ to the dependence parameter for a number of single copula models, specially in the Archimedean class. Since the mathematical aspects are relatively simple and a correlation-based approach is appealing, the estimation method based on these formulas has been favoured in the literature. From the standard error of the Kendall τ, an approximation of the standard error of these estimates can be derived, but, with much less effort, such an approximation can be obtained from random sampling in a bivariate distribution whose cdf is a given copula.

sec.title: Maximum Likelihood Methods
sec.p: Among the various ML estimation procedures for copulas we have adopted (like most authors) the canonical maximum likelihood (CML) method, which does not assume any parametric form of the marginal distributions.14In this way, we have the advantage that we do not need to specify the marginal distribution, and therefore, the estimates are robust with respect to errors in the specification of the marginals.

Let X be a variable and (x1, x2,…., xN) a set of observations of X. The empirical cdf is
(7) F^X(x) = #{xt≤x}N .

A set of joint observations (xt, yt) of X and Y can be transformed into a set of points (ut, vt) in the unit square by defining ut = F^X(xt)vt = F^Y(yt). 15 The CML method consists of maximising the log-likelihood of the data set formed by these points. If c (u, v; θ) is the copula density, the log-likelihood is
(8) ℓ(θ)=∑t=1Nlog[c(ut,vt;θ)].

For simple, one-parameter models like the Gumbel and Clayton copulas, the negative log-likelihood has a U-shaped graph, so that the minimum can be easily found by linear search. More computational power is needed for mixture copulas, since the number of parameters is increased. When the weight is fixed, there are two dependence parameters, one by component. Direct maximisation of the log-likelihood is more difficult, due to the sum of terms inside the logarithm and the estimates could be strongly dependent on the initial estimates. Nevertheless, we have found the R command optimise, which implements L-BFGS-B algorithm of Byrd et al. (1995), as provided by the R statistical software, powerful enough to yield fast ML estimates of the dependence parameters.

For the general mixture, the weight is a third parameter that has to be estimated. The EM algorithm (Dempster et al. 1977) is typically used for dealing with mixture distributions (not only copulas).16 It is an iterative procedure that require two steps: the expectation (E) and the maximisation (M) step. In the M-step, the weight is fixed and the two dependence parameters are estimated by the ML method, as in the 50-50 mixture. In the E-step, the components of the mixture are fixed and the weight is changed to maximise the likelihood.

For a model with k parameters, the AIC value is equal to
(9) AIC= –2 log(max. likelihood) + 2k.

The use of the AIC for the comparison of different models is widely extended, since it contains a penalty for increasing the number of parameters, and can be applied when the competitor models are not related. In particular, it has been used in order to compare the performance of different copula models with financial data.17 However, for nested models, that is, such that one results from the other by fixing some of the parameters, the classical likelihood ratio (LR) test18 allows not only the comparison between the models but also produces a significance level.

sec.title: Chi-square Distance Methods
sec.p: The goodness of fit of ML estimates is usually measured by the log-likelihood or some statistic related to it, like the AIC. An alternative approach is based on matching the proportions predicted by the model (the expected proportions) to those found in the data (the observed realisations), by means of a distance. The use of distances in this article is restricted to (Euclidean) L2 distances.19

Here, we are interested in the L2 distance between a copula model C (e.g., a prespecified Archimedean or mixture copula) and the empirical copula, defined as
(10) C^(u,v) = #{ut ≤ u, vt ≤ v}N = #{xt ≤ F^X−1(u), yt ≤ F^Y−1(v)}N.

L2 distances can be used in two ways: to compare models and to estimate the parameters of a pre-specified model. In the first case, the distances between the empirical copula associated to a data set and different copula models fitted to the data set are compared, in order to select that model for which the distance is the shortest.20 For instance, Gatfaoui (2003) has used it to choose among different copula models21 for the dependence between the returns of the S&P stock index and the credit spreads of different companies.

The approach of this study is slightly different. First, we do not use a distance between the values of two copulas in a grid of points, but one between the proportions derived from these values. Second, given the large sample size and the fact that not all the areas of the square are equally important, we put, on each term of the sum giving the distance, a weight equal to the reciprocal of the proportion given by one of the copulas. This weighted L2 distance coincides with the χ2 statistic associated to a cross-tabulation of the proportions of the empirical copula and the theoretical copula on the regions of a partition of the unit square.

The χ2 statistic is defined as
(11) χ2 = N ∑i (pi − p^i)2pi .

Here,p^i is the proportion predicted by the model for the ith region and pi is the observed proportion. It can be seen as the sum of squares of the residualsei = (N/pi)1/2(pi − p^i). Thus, the regions where the deviation between predicted and observed proportions is most relevant can be identified through the residuals with higher absolute values.

We have tried here a special partition proposed by Patton (2003), which gives more weight to the tails and allows a fast interpretation of the residuals. Patton (2003) has suggested a ‘hit test’ for copulas, based on a partition of the unit square into eight zones, shown in Figure 1. Since the sum of the proportions of the eight zones must equal to 1, we can match this χ2 value against the 95 per cent critical value for 7 degrees of freedom, which is 14.07. The Patton hit test was applied by Fortin and Kuzmics (2002) to various mixture copulas.

sec.title: Basic Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: In this research, we have used daily data of the DataStream Global Indices, extracted from the DataStream database, which contains market data for 40 national equity markets.22Each index has 6 levels. The level 1, called the Market index, has been used here. The seven Latin American countries’ indices covered by DataStream are Argentina (Arg), Brazil (Bra), Chile (Chl), Colombia (Col), Mexico (Мех), Peru (Per) and Venezuela (Ven). Our data set also includes two regional indices, representing all Latin American (LA) and the world (Wrd) markets, respectively. It covers the period from 5 July 1994 to 27 February 2004, for a total of 2,519 observations.

The summary statistics of the daily returns of these indices are presented in Panel A of Table 2. The daily mean returns range from a minimum of 0.00023 for Argentina to a maximum of 0.00045 for Brazil. The minimum and maximum daily standard deviations are 0.010 and 0.026, respectively, achieved by Chile and Venezuela.

tr.td: Panel B: Skewness, Kurtosis and Sharpe’s Ratio

sec.p: The occurrence of negative skewness and excess kurtosis in stock market returns, often mentioned in the literature,23 has been found in numerous empirical studies. Nevertheless, it is plainly evident that, for these data, departure from normality is more due to kurtosis24 than to skewness. Moreover, all the indices show positive kurtosis, whereas three indices, out of seven, have a negatively skewed distribution. Maximum and minimum skewness are achieved by Peru (0.52) and Venezuela (–3.44). All the indexes have kurtosis above 3.

The linear (Pearson) and Kendall correlations are presented in Table 3. These figures indicate a positive relation between the market returns. Also, none of the correlations reported exceeds 0.50. On the one hand, the highest coefficient of correlation is achieved by the pair Bra–Mex (0.487) and the second highest by the pair Bra–Chl (0.473). On the other hand, the lowest correlations are found in Colombia (0.08 on average) and in Venezuela (0.14 on average).

sec.title: Tail Dependence
sec.p: This section is devoted to the analysis of tail dependence among our set of seven Latin American countries. Additionally, we examine the differences between the coefficients of lower and upper tail dependence, signalling for tail dependence asymmetry. We also report tail dependence coefficients for two regional indices: the Latin American index and the world index.

One of the main traits of a copula model is the relative weight on the upper and lower tails. Some stress more on the upper tail (Gumbel copula), and others on the lower tail (Clayton copula). The ability of copulas to capture tail dependence is a crucial property in our study, since it informs on the tendency of Latin American countries to boom or to crash simultaneously. In this regard, Pagán and Soydemir (2001) documented that the response of three Latin American countries to downturns and upturns in Mexico equity market is not symmetric; responses to a strong negative market movement clearly outweigh that of a strong upturn. In the same line, Rodriguez (2007), controlling the data from state-varying volatility, documented that although overall dependence can increase, change in tail behaviour can differ widely across markets, with negative tail dependence being more prevalent in times of financial turmoil.

Table 4 reports the empirical lower and upper tail dependence coefficients. These results are interesting by a number of reasons. On the one hand, our sample presents relevant asymmetry. In 14 out of the 21 country pairs, lower tail dependence is more pronounced. Colombia is the only country displaying higher upper than lower tail dependence in all cases. Lower tail dependence is maximum in the pair Bra–Mex (0.40), whereas upper tail dependence is maximum in Chl–Arg (0.32). On the other hand, the pronounced left coupling displayed among these markets is implying that the assumption of joint normality is violated in a dangerous direction. Note that our true joint distributions display a clear tendency towards extreme negative events. Thus, when most needed, cross market diversification may be of limited use as a means of reducing portfolio risk. All this suggest that the margins should be modelled with non-normal copulas that allow for asymmetry. Chollete et al. (2009), working on Latin American countries, documented that a canonical vine structure where the margins are characterised by non-normal copulas (but symmetric dependence) performs better than the all-symmetric models.

sec.p: Knowing that left extreme co-movements are likely to occur is of paramount importance, for example, for a portfolio manager designing his ex-ante diversification strategy.25 To effectively help portfolio managers, an accurate description of asset dependencies ought to be based on models that can capture the asymmetries in the extreme realisations. A normal-based copula model does not seem to be able to model such dependence asymmetries. Note that we have two points to consider when using elliptical copulas, the presence of fat tails and the asymmetry in the tails. Since the Gaussian copula has a null asymptotic coefficient for both lower and upper tail dependence, it will incorrectly model the extreme dependence. Student’s t copula can capture fat tails, but not tail dependence asymmetry.

As we have already mentioned, an important feature of mixture copulas is that they allow for different degrees of tail dependence. As an illustration, we have used the CSC copula (with w1 = w2 = 0.5) to obtain the values of Table 5. This model has two parameters, one corresponding to the Clayton component (θ1) and the other to the Survival Clayton component (θ2). Estimates of these parameters have been obtained by the ML method, separately for each pair.

caption.p: Asymptotic Tail Dependence for Clayton–Survival Clayton Copula

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Values above the diagonal correspond to lower tail and those below to upper tail dependence.

sec.p: The CSC copula model stresses both upper and lower tail dependence. More specifically, since we have λL = 2–1/θ1 and λU = 0 for the Clayton component, and λL = 0 and λU = 2–1/θ2 for the Survival Clayton component, we obtain λL = 2–(1+1/θ1) and λU = 2–(1+1/θ2); when –1 < θ < 0, λL = λU= 0 for both the Clayton and Survival Clayton copulas. As in Table 4, lower tail dependence is stronger than upper tail dependence. The maximum values of λL (0.255) and λU (0.197) are those of the pair Bra–Mex.

Comparing the two tables, we see that a simple two-parameter model seems to capture the asymmetric patterns underlying our data, Regrettably, the parameter estimates do not inform us about how well this model fits. In the following section, we deal with the issue of goodness of fit for the different models.

sec.title: Empirical Results for the Different Models
sec.p: In this section, we present the empirical results for different models. First, we report in the subsection ‘Results for the Archimedean Models’, the [semi]parametric and non-parametric estimation results for four Archimedean models, namely, the Clayton, Frank, Gumbel and Joe copula models, and a mixture model, the Clayton–Survival Clayton copula model. Next, we present in the subsection ‘Results for the Mixture Models’, the results for other general mixture copula models, with unrestricted weights.

Since a presentation of a complete analysis for all the pairs and all the copula models would consume too much space, details are limited to the pair Bra–Mex, used here for illustration. Together with the χ2 statistic related to the hit test, we report the contributions of the eight regions.26 Following other authors, and only for informative purposes, we also report AIC values.

sec.title: Results for the Archimedean Models
sec.p: The results obtained for single Archimedean copulas are clearly inferior to those of the mixture CSC copula that are reported in Table 6, which illustrates the diversity of the dependence structures found in the data. The values above the diagonal correspond to the Clayton parameter and those below to the Survival Clayton parameter.

sec.p: In Table 7, we document the χ2 statistic and the contribution of each region to the total value in the hit test suggested by Patton (2003). Panel A contains the ML estimates and Panel B the τ based estimates. If we examine the contribution of each particular region, the deficiencies of each copula are unveiled. For instance, in the Clayton copula, about 80 per cent of the χ2 value comes from region 2.27 In other words, the Clayton copula does not account for the upper tail dependence, and therefore, is a predictably bad performer in the upper-right quadrant. On the contrary, Clayton copula could be of great help in the case of variables with strong lower tail dependence (regions 1 and 3). The inverse pattern is displayed by the Gumbel copula. Almost 79 per cent of the χ2 value corresponds to region 1. Leaving apart the CSC copula, the minimum χ2value is found for the Clayton copula (38.42) in Panel B. The better performance of the Clayton copula is not surprising, because of the tail dependence found in this data set.

sec.p: Table 6 also shows that, in most cases, the difference between the two estimates, θ^ML and θ^τ, is small but, in other cases, it can be relevant. For instance, for the pair Bra–Mex, in the Clayton model, θ^ML=0.739 and θ^τ = 0.922, and in the Gumbel model, θ^ML= 1.424 and θ^τ= 1.461. These estimates are only informative because we cannot say which copula fits better, although a relevant difference in parameter estimates obtained by different methods suggests that the model is inadequate.

With single Archimedean copulas, we must choose between modelling lower or upper tail dependence. Intuitively, if one could construct a mixture of two copulas modelling different tail patterns, the model should fit substantially better than any rigid single model. This intuition is strongly confirmed in Table 7. It is clear that the best model is the CSC copula. The improvement in the goodness of fit, relative to the second best, is quite clear, no matter if we use ML or τ based estimates.

Comparing Clayton and CSC copulas, we observe that the mixture improves the fit in six of the eight regions tested, the major improvement coming from the upper-right quadrant (region 2). This region contributes 80 per cent of the χ2 value under the Clayton model, but less than 0.1 per cent under the CSC model. Without any doubt the hit test results strongly support the CSC copula. Using the ML parameter estimates, we find that the CSC model is not rejected in 18 out of 21 cases,28 whereas the Clayton copula is rejected in 10 cases.29 Using the 95 per cent χ2 critical value, the Frank, Gumbel and Joe models are rejected for all pairs, and for both estimation methods.

sec.title: Results for the Mixture Models
sec.p: The results of the subsection ‘Results for the Archimedean Models’ support our intuition about the gains that can be obtained by simply mixing copulas with different tail dependence features. Combining copulas with high right tail dependence with copulas presenting high left tail dependence yields a more flexible and accurate model. The improvement in the goodness of fit with the CSC copula was dramatic. Once the superiority of mixtures over single copulas for these data has been clearly established, we turn our attention to the choice of the mixture.

We present now the results for four mixture copula models: Clayton–Gumbel (CG), Clayton–Frank (CF), Clayton–Survival Clayton (CSC) and Gumbel–Survival Gumbel (GSG). Each model was estimated using the EM-algorithm. In addition to the weight and the association parameters estimates, we also report the (maximum) log-likelihood, the χ2 statistic for the hit test and the contributions (percentage) of the eight regions. The AIC is reported only as complementary information.

Since the GSG mixture outperforms the other three models in 19 out of the 21 possible country pairs, we only present the results for this mixture.30 The pairs for which the GSG mixture model do not outperform the others are Per–Ven and Bra–Col. For Per–Ven the χ2 = 1.79 against a χ2 = 2.55 for the GSG model, while the χ2 statistic for Bra–Col is 7.13 against a χ2 = 10.30 of the GSG model.

Table 8 displays the parameter estimation results for the GSG mixture model. The weights for the Gumbel copula are well below the 50 per cent in 14 out of the 21 possible country pairs, that is, the dominant component is the Survival Gumbel copula. The estimated weights underpin the results of the subsection ‘Tail Dependence’ under the section ‘Description of the Data’, indicating the importance of lower tail dependence for Latin American countries. The riskiest dependence structure is displayed by the Bra–Per pair, with a Gumbel weight of less than 16 per cent. The safest dependence structure is displayed by Ven–Col, with a Gumbel weight of 91 per cent. The χ2 values for both Bra–Per (7.54) and Ven–Col (7.07) are not enough for rejecting the estimated mixture model. Our results are in perfect consonance with those of Chollete et al. (2005), even though their sample is constituted by five developed countries. These authors documented a Survival Gumbel copula weight exceeding the 50 per cent in 6 out of 10 cases. This empirical evidence points towards a dependence structure presenting strong lower tail dependence.

We see in Table 8 how countries with essentially the same correlation can have substantially different dependence structures. Take for example the case of Arg–Мех and Chl–Mex. Both pairs have (Pearson) correlation around 0.42. However, while the dependence structure for the pair Arg–Mex is better represented by a GSG copula with w = 0.56, the dependence structure for the pair Chl–Мех is better modelled using w = 0.33. The implications of these results are extremely important when managing portfolios. From the point of view of portfolio theory, if we have a portfolio with only one asset, say Mexico, it would be indifferent to invest our money in Argentina or Chile, in order to hedge our asset position against possible bad times. But this is simply false. If we define a market crash as when the return is in its lowest 10th percentile, the number of joint crashes for the pair Arg–Mex is 87, while for Chl–Mex it is 91. Clearly, investing our money in Chile can be a mistake because our new portfolio, now composed by Chile and Mexico, would be riskier than if we had invested our money in Argentina.

sec.p: If we simply assume a joint Gaussian model for the pair Chile/Mexico, the predicted number of occurrences when both markets are in their lowest 10th percentile is about 69. Here, working under Gaussian assumptions can seriously jeopardise our portfolio investment decisions. In contrast, our GSG mixture copula model predicts 85 occurrences of a joint market crash. Even though our GSG model prediction is below the actual number, it happens to be much better than the Gaussian prediction. The results of Chollete et al. (2007) support our findings that symmetric models fail to assess diversification benefits in the worse direction. They show that, when computing the VaR (Value at Risk) for Latin American countries, the use of Gaussian or Student-t models underestimates the risk of a portfolio by 6 per cent in the case of a 99 per cent VaR. Mashal and Zeevi (2002) also stated that elliptical-based models underemphasise the country coupling and therefore, indicate incorrectly the cross-border holding gain.

Another important issue underlying the subsections ‘Results for the Mixture Models’ and ‘Country–World Dependence’ is that of modelling the dynamics of each marginal distribution. We have documented that our empirical returns are not normally distributed and that, as stressed by Fortin and Kuzmics (2002), Patton (2002), Rockinger and Jondeau (2001) and Vaz de Melo and Kolev (2006), this could be due to volatility effects. To control the effect of stochastic volatility, we have followed two stages. First, we fitted different ARMA models to each marginal distribution. We selected the ARMA(2, 3) model because it was the one with the highest AIC. Second, we fitted an univariate GARCH(1, 1) model with Gaussian innovations to each residual distribution obtained in the previous stage. The results using a different GARCH model do not change in a significant way; therefore, we decided to use the simplest one. We have then analysed the dependence of the filtered returns (residuals) among countries.

As we see in Table 9, the results do not change substantially when analysing filtered returns. The weights for the Survival Gumbel component are roughly the same and in particular cases, the weight for the component modelling left tail dependence is insignificantly greater than the case for empirical returns. Also, the contributions of region 1 to the χ2 statistic of the hit test are lower than in the case of using empirical returns, while those for the region 3 are mixed. These results indicate the suitability of the model when trying to capture lower tail dependence. Finally, the association parameters are in the same range as in the case of empirical returns.

sec.p: Our results are different (but not contradictory) from those recently obtained by Vaz de Melo and Kolev (2006). They have documented a change in the dependence structure, once the empirical returns are FIGARCH-filtered. They found that, after controlling out for volatility effects, the dependence structure among country returns diminishes or disappears. In our results the dependence structure and the asymmetry displayed do not significantly change. In this section, we have documented the superiority of mixture copula models over the simple ones. In fact, part of the difference in the results could be explained because Vaz de Melo and Kolev (2006) used simple (one parameter) copula models and we used mixture copula models. Our results are in line with Hu (2003), who has found significant left tail dependence in five out of the six pairs of developed country pairs studied.

sec.title: Country–World Dependence
sec.p: Certainly, Latin American countries not only depend on their own region but they are also influenced by other regions or, more generally, by international markets. Therefore, it is also important to understand how these seven countries behave among themselves and with respect to the world market. In the subsections ‘Results for the Archimedean Models’ and ‘Results for the Mixture Models’, we have reported estimates of association parameters for single and mixture copula models among 21 pair of countries. This subsection deals with the estimation of dependence parameters among the seven Latin American countries with the MSCI world index. Table 10 contains the results for the mixture models presented in the subsection ‘Results for the Mixture Models’.

The first thing to note is that none of the mixture models outperforms the others clearly. However, the CF and the GSG appear to make a better job describing the dependence structure. Second, it is interesting to note the change in the shape of the dependence structure. The CF mixture model outperforms the other in four out of the seven pairs analysed (Argentina, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela), while the GSG mixture model fits well for the two biggest countries of the region, Brazil and Mexico.

In the previous subsection we have put in evidence a clear left tail dependence structure, but when modelling the dependence between countries and the world, this asymmetric pattern is slightly less pronounced. The fact that the CF mixture is composed by an asymmetric copula (Clayton) and a symmetric one (Frank) suggests that part of the lower tail dependence is ‘diluted’. These could be explained because the world index is an aggregation of many different countries, producing thus a positive diversification effect that smoothes the negative asymmetric dependence.

We see in Table 10 that the dependence for Brazil and Mexico with the world continues to be better represented by the GSG mixture. Moreover, the weight for the Survival Gumbel components are wsg = 0.75 and wsg = 0.66 for Brazil and Mexico, respectively. These results indicate that the strong negative asymmetric dependence continues to be present.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we have tested various models for the structure of dependence across seven Latin American stock markets. We built our analysis in two stages. In the first stage, the structure of dependence is modelled using four single Archimedean copulas and a mixture copula model with fixed weights, the CSC model. In the second stage, we estimate more flexible models mixing copulas with different tail dependence properties. Four mixture copula models are estimated: Clayton–Gumbel, Clayton–Frank, Clayton–Survival Clayton and Gumbel–Survival Gumbel.

Regarding the estimation methods, we document three main findings. First, we recommend to use the maximum likelihood method, since our simulations show that it possesses a negligible bias and the lowest standard errors. Second, it is extremely important to count with an objective tool to judiciously test the goodness of fit. Third, Patton’s (2003) hit test provides a direct assessment of the goodness of fit for the different models considered.

Our results in the first stage support the CSC copula model, which provides the best fit. Compared with the other four models, the CSC model improves the fit in the upper-right quadrant. The superiority of the CSC over the single Clayton copula model provides evidence of the existence of right and left tail dependence. This result is in line with the findings of Chollete et al. (2005) who also documented right and left tail dependence.

In the second stage, we find that the superiority of the mixture copula models compared with the single Archimedean models is devastating. Among the mixture models, for country-to-country dependence, the Gumbel–Survival Gumbel model provides the best fit, on the average. Our findings support the presence of asymmetric tail dependence in the majority of the country pairs studied. Moreover, we document consistently large weights on the Survival Gumbel component. Our evidence shows that there is a clear tendency towards extreme negative events. To know this kind of patterns is crucial for a portfolio manager, because her/his ability to reduce the portfolio risk using intra-regional cross-market diversification will be limited.

In the case for country-to-world dependence, we do not find a unique model, but Clayton–Frank and Gumbel–Survival Gumbel clearly fit better than the other two mixture models. We document the existence of a slightly lower tail dependence, suggesting a positive diversification effect. For both mixtures, we find that the large weight is for the component that captures the lower tail dependence. Another important point is that when analysing ARMA-GARCH filtered returns the results remain the same.

These findings have two important implications. On one hand, they imply that when most needed diversification benefits will not be fully available. On the other hand, the cross-market dependence is asymmetric with a greater probability for extreme losses. To put it clear, Latin American stock markets are not particularly likely to boom together, but all the contrary.
